Let Stsuperscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡S^{t} be the set of all registered clients at round tğ‘¡t and ğ’«tsuperscriptğ’«ğ‘¡{\mathcal{P}}^{t} be a subset of it drawn from a distribution Pâ€‹(SÏ„;Ï„=t)ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğ‘†ğœğœğ‘¡P(S^{\tau};\tau=t).
The server broadcasts the cloud model ğœ½tâˆ’1superscriptğœ½ğ‘¡1{\bm{\theta}}^{t-1} to all the selected clients.
Each client iâˆˆğ’«tğ‘–superscriptğ’«ğ‘¡i\in{\mathcal{P}}^{t}, optimizes the cloud model based on its local objective and transmits the optimized client model, ğœ½itsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘¡{\bm{\theta}}_{i}^{t} back to the server.
The server aggregates the received parameters and prepares a new cloud model for the next round.
TableÂ 1 lists the most frequently used symbols in this paper along with their meanings. Note that the aggregate model is the average of client models over values of iâˆˆğ’«tğ‘–superscriptğ’«ğ‘¡i\in{\mathcal{P}}^{t}.
Likewise, aggregate gradients are the average of the client gradients.

references: TableÂ 2 compare the performance of our model to all the baselines in various settings with 100 clients. The results show that our algorithm is effective in all settings. The 1000-device experiments confirm our arguments about the large-scale cross-device setting and practicality of AdaBest in comparison to the baselines. Our algorithm has notable gain both in the speed of convergence and the generalization performance. This gain is only overtaken for some benchmarks in full client participation settings (CP=100%) where the best Î²ğ›½\beta is chosen close to one. According to Remark 5, and the fact that in full participation |ğ’«t||St|=1superscriptğ’«ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡1\frac{|{\mathcal{P}}^{t}|}{|S^{t}|}=1 and ti=tiâ€²+1subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¡â€²ğ‘–1t_{i}=t^{\prime}_{i}+1 for all feasible iğ‘–i and tğ‘¡t, FedDyn and AdaBest become nearly identical in these settings. In FigureÂ 3, we show the impact of scaling the number of clients in both balanced and imbalanced settings for the same dataset and the same number of clients sampled per round (10 clients). During the hyper-parameter tuning we noticed that the sensitivity of FedDyn and AdaBest to their Î¼ğœ‡\mu is small specially for the cases with larger number of clients.

In Figure 1, we showed an experimental case of low client participation to demonstrate how â€–ğœ½tâ€–normsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘¡\|{\bm{\theta}}^{t}\| is associated with instability of FedDyn. In this experiment, the training split of CIFAR100 is partitioned over 110011001100 clients from which 100010001000 is used for training. The partitioning is balanced in terms of number of examples per client and the labels are skewed according to our Î±=0.3ğ›¼0.3\alpha=0.3 heterogeneity setup (see Section 4.4 for detailed explanation). In each round, 555 clients are drawn uniformly at random. This low client participation rate is more likely to occur in a large-scale (in terms of number of clients) cross-device FL compared to the setting used for reporting the performances in TableÂ 2 and most of those of our prior works. In Figure 4 we repeat the same experiment; except that a much simpler FL task is defined. In this experiment the training split of EMNIST-L dataset is partitioned into 110 clients, 100 of which are used for training. Partitions are IID (labels are not skewed). Even though this task is much simpler than the previous one, still FedDyn fails to converge when the training continues for a large number of rounds.

During the hyper-parameter tuning phase, we only tune Î²ğ›½\beta of AdaBest and set its Î¼ğœ‡\mu constantly to 0.020.020.02. This is done throughout all the experiments except the experiment presented in this section which especially investigates the sensitivity of AdaBest to varying Î¼ğœ‡\mu. Therefore, in practice we have not treated Î¼ğœ‡\mu as a hyper-parameter but rather chose the value that works best for FedDyn. For this experiment, we use the same setup as the one presented in Section D.3 on EMNIST-L dataset. The only difference is that we vary Î¼ğœ‡\mu in the range of {0.02Ã—2(k)}k=1k=3superscriptsubscript0.02superscript2ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ‘˜3\{0.02\times 2^{(k)}\}_{k=1}^{k=3}. Figure 6 depicts the outcome of this experiment along with the result of the same analysis on FedDyn so it would be easy to compare the sensitivity of each of these algorithms to their local factor Î¼ğœ‡\mu. As suggested by the top left subplot in this Figure, AdaBest can even achieve higher numbers in terms of the test accuracy than what is reported in TableÂ 2. The scales on the vertical axis of the subplots related to AdaBest (on the left column) are zoomed-in to better show the stability of our algorithm throughout the training. On the other hand, the performance and stability of FedDyn shows to be heavily relied on the choice of Î¼ğœ‡\mu when the training continues for a large number of rounds.

TableÂ 3 shows the notation we use for formulating the
costs of these algorithms.
AlgorithmÂ 2 is an exact repetition of Algorithm
1 except that the compute cost of operations of interest are included
as comments.
These costs are summed in tables TableÂ 4 and Table
5 for the client and server sides, respectively.
According to these tables, AdaBest has lower client-side and server-side compute
costs than SCAFFOLD/m and FedDyn.

All the three algorithms require the same amount of storage, on the clients and the server. Each client is supposed to store a set of local gradient estimates with size nğ‘›n (see TableÂ 3), noted as ğ’‰itsuperscriptsubscriptğ’‰ğ‘–ğ‘¡{\bm{h}}_{i}^{t}. Likewise, each algorithm stores the same number of variables on the server so that estimates are forwarded to the next rounds. These variables are introduced with ğ’‰tsuperscriptğ’‰ğ‘¡{\bm{h}}^{t} in SCAFFOLD/m and FedDyn but with ğœ½Â¯tâˆ’1superscriptÂ¯ğœ½ğ‘¡1\bar{{\bm{\theta}}}^{t-1} in AdaBest.
